options: Contact the DVLA and inform them of your concerns
Ask the patient to contact the DVLA themselves or otherwise you will
Contact the patient and discuss your professional duty to inform the DVLA
Reassure them that you won't break confidentiality but persuade them of the need to stop driving
Discuss with the GP Partners about removing him from the Practice list
questions:
You are working as a ST1 doctor in general practice and have recently seen Mr Jones, who is known to have epilepsy and has just been discharged following a seizure. You have advised him twice before that he needs to stop driving and inform the DVLA. The next day you see him driving past the surgery.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC have recently updated their guidance on raising concerns with the DVLA:

http://www.gmc-uk.org/news/27477.asp

You have warned Mr Jones on more than one occasion before about the risks of driving and he clearly hasn't heeded your advice. You therefore need to inform the DVLA. The GMC advise that we should inform patients before we are about to breech confidentiality.

You have given Mr Jones a chance to stop driving before so giving him a further chance is a relatively poor option.

In terms of option D, the GMC are clear - there is a public interest in breaking confidentiality in this situation.

Removing him from the Practice list is the worst option - by doing this you are abandoning your responsibilities to the patient and wider public.

options: Explain your concern about the frequency of prescriptions
Give her a limited 7 day supply and review her following that
Give her an official warning as prescription fraud is one of the criteria for removing a patient from the practice list
Presume the patient is truthful and prescribe a months' supply as requested
Explain about how you have a responsibility to protect limited NHS resources
Contact the police due to the possibility she may be selling a controlled drug
Refuse to prescribe the dihydrocodeine
Get more information about the patient from the other doctors at the surgery
questions:
You are a GP registrar doing a morning surgery. A 36-year-old woman with a history of alcohol abuse and back pain comes in. She requests a repeat prescription of dihydrocodeine. You can see from the computer screen that she had a months' supply 7 days ago, a months' supply 2 weeks ago and a months' supply 3 weeks ago. On discussing this she states that on one occasion she lost the script and on another her handbag was stolen.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Clearly the worry here is that the patient is either abusing the dihydrocodeine herself or passing it on to a third party. There is however a small possibility that the patient is telling the truth and hence a calm and reasonable approach is needed.

It is best to be honest with the patient and explain your concerns about the frequency at which she picks up the medication. If she is never challenged about her behaviour then it is possible that she feels it is reasonable. Giving a limited supply is a good option as it allows her to continue the medication but prevents scope for abuse. As you have genuine concerns about that patient it is reasonable to discuss her with other doctors to see if there is a pattern of behaviour.

Simply prescribing a months' supply is likely to perpetuate the situation. Whether she is abusing the drug or not a talk about NHS resources is unlikely to help. She is not committing prescription fraud as she has had a valid prescription each time.

options: Ask a senior colleague at the practice to speak with her about driving
Contact the DVLA about the patient's ongoing driving
Explore the patient's understanding of her restriction from driving and reiterate that it is unsafe for her to drive
Ignore the issue of her driving as it is a matter for the specialist to deal with
Tell the patient that she must stop driving and inform the DVLA or you will have to do so yourself
questions:
You are an F2 at a GP practice. You are seeing a patient who had a new diagnosis of epilepsy made in secondary care. You see in the clinic letter that the specialist has recorded having told her she must stop driving and notify the DVLA of her new diagnosis.

When you ask her how she came to her appointment, she states she drove herself.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
GMC guidance on notifying the DVLA about unsafe drivers is clear:

If a patient has a condition or is undergoing treatment that could impair their fitness to drive, you should:
  • Explain this to the patient and tell them they have a legal duty to inform the DVLA.
  • Tell the patient that you may be obliged to disclose relevant medical information about them, in confidence, to the DVLA if they continue to drive when they are not fit to do so.

Explore the patient's understanding of her restriction from driving and reiterate the reason for it as required is the most appropriate option. It may be that she simply misunderstood what the specialist told her, and a frank discussion about it may convince her to stop driving.

Tell the patient that she must stop driving and inform the DVLA or you will have to do so yourself is an appropriate action and follows GMC guidance. However, exploring her reasoning for still driving (as above) and explaining why it is unsafe for her to drive will make it more likely that she cooperates with the process and follows your request.

Ask a senior colleague at the practice to speak with her about driving is somewhat appropriate as it does solve the problem at hand. However, you may be unduly burdening a busy colleague and should be well able to handle this issue yourself.

Contact the DVLA about the patient's ongoing driving is somewhat inappropriate. As per the GMC guidance advice, you should only do this when you are unable to convince the patient not to drive. Furthermore, you should tell the patient that you will notify the DVLA first. However, it does address the issue of her unsafe driving.

Ignore the issue of her driving as it is a matter for the specialist to deal with is extremely inappropriate. You have a duty as a doctor to take action when someone is driving unsafely - it is not just an issue for secondary care to address. If someone were to come to harm because of your inaction, you could be held responsible.

title: GMC: Confidentiality: patients' fitness to drive and reporting concerns to the DVLA or DVA
body:
Trust is a central part of the doctor-patient relationship and is part of our daily practice. This can be put at risk by breaking confidentiality. Fitness to drive is one area where it is important to know what is expected of you, in both a legal and moral sense. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)/ Vehicle Agency (DVA) are legally responsible for deciding if a person is medically unfit to drive. This means they need to know if a person holding a driving licence has a condition or is undergoing treatment that may affect their safety as a driver.

First off, it is the driver's legal responsibility to tell the DVLA or DVA about any condition or treatment. Doctors should alert patients to conditions and treatments that might affect their ability to drive and remind them of their duty to tell the appropriate agency. However, doctors may need to make a decision about whether to disclose relevant information without consent if a patient is unfit to drive but continues to do so.

You should always ask for a patient's consent before disclosing information for the protection of others (if it is safe, appropriate or practicable to do so). If it is not possible to seek consent or the patient has refused, disclosing personal information may be justified. This is particularly when there is a risk of death or serious harm to others. The benefits of disclosure must outweigh the interest in keeping the information confidential.

Problems with breaking confidentiality:
  • Patients may avoid seeking medical help, or may under-report symptoms.
  • Consultations may become more strained or mistrusting.
  • Complaints may be made against the doctor or practice.

You should not ask for consent if you have already decided to disclose information in the public interest but, if possible, you should tell the patient about your intention to disclose personal information. If the patient objects to the disclosure you should consider any reasons they give for objecting.

Reasons that the patient may object to sharing of information:
  • They are concerned about the implications for work, family or other areas.
  • In principle, they do not feel that it is your place to share the information.
  • They do not understand the reason for the information sharing.

When deciding whether the public interest outweighs potential harm, consider:
  • The potential harm or distress to the patient arising from the disclosure.
  • The potential harm to trust in doctors generally.
  • The potential harm to others if the information is not disclosed.
  • The potential benefits to an individual or society due to the release of the information.
  • The nature of the information to be disclosed, and any views expressed by the patient.
  • Whether the harms can be avoided or benefits gained without breaching the patient's privacy.

When diagnosing a patient's condition, or providing or arranging treatment, you should consider whether the condition or treatment may affect their ability to drive safely. To help determine this, you can refer to the DVLA's guidance on assessing fitness to drive. You may also seek the advice of an experienced colleague or the DVLA medical adviser.

If a patient has a condition or is undergoing treatment that could impair their fitness to drive, you should:
  • Explain this to the patient and tell them that they have a legal duty to inform the DVLA.
  • Tell the patient that you may be obliged to disclose relevant medical information about them, if they continue to drive when they are not fit to do so.
  • Make a note of any advice you have given to a patient in their medical record.
  • If a patient is incapable of understanding this advice, such as in cognitive impairment, you should inform the DVLA as soon as practicable.

The patient is welcome to seek a second medical opinion, and you should help facilitate this. However, you should still advise them not to drive in the meantime. If you become aware that a patient is continuing to drive when they may not be fit to do so, you should make every reasonable effort to persuade them to stop. Only then, would you consider breaching confidentiality. This is not an easy decision to make, but may be necessary for the safety of others.

options: Put a series of posters around the hospital about the missing phone
Call the police
Reassure the patient that an incident form will be completed and senior staff notified
Inform the ward manager
Offer to look around his bedside
Search the lockers of all the other patients on the ward
Ask security to search all staff on the ward
Politely remind him that you want to focus on clinical work and ask him to speak to hospital security
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in General Medicine. A patient who has been admitted on your ward for the past three days complains on the ward round that he can't find his mobile phone. He is worried one of the other patients or a member of staff may have stolen it. When you ring his number no ringtone can be heard.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The loss of personal property can aggravate an already stressful time for patients and hence needs to be handled sensitively. Looking around the bedside is something he will have almost certainly done himself but demonstrates that you care and are taking his problem seriously. The ward manager is responsible completing a lost property form and taking overall charge of the situation. Reassuring the patient that an incident form will be completed and senior staff notified lets the patient know that the issue will be logged and acted upon.

Calling the police is not one of the best three responses given that the patient has only just reported the matter. It may be that the phone turns up over the next few hours. Carrying out a search of other patients or members of staff is an invasion of privacy and hence not legal. Missing posters are useful for lost pets but unlikely to reap results when looking for a lost phone.

questions:
You are on a doctors mess night out and the theme is scrubs or stethoscopes. As the night goes on many of your colleagues become very vocal as they become more inebriated and they start making loud remarks about members of the public. You start to get concerned that they are bringing the profession into disrepute.

Chose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC guidelines clearly states: You must make sure that your conduct justifies your patients trust in you and the publics' trust in the profession. With this in mind, what is the most appropriate course of action, bearing in mind you are recognisable as a group of medics?

Trying to improve the situation is always going to be the best option: both in the short term (options B and C), and in the longer term: by discussing directly with the mess president to influence themes / behaviour on future nights out (option G).

Option A and H will not change the situation, which if you believe is of genuine concern.

Option D is an over-reaction at this point. The GMC would not get involved unless a complaint or criminal activity has taken place. Even then, local measures should be pursued first.

Option E is not as good as addressing the situation yourself.

Option F is an over-reaction at this point.

See: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/goodmedicalpractice/20462.asp

questions:
You are a GP registrar. A patient presents with spreading, irregular pigmented lesion on her leg. On examination it looks almost certainly to be a malignant melanoma. You tell the patient that you are concerned it may be a serious form of skin cancer. The patient replies that she doesn't believe in 'western medicine' and wants to use 'traditional remedies' such as homeopathy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at autonomy in a competent adult. Whilst her decision may seem illogical to you this is not grounds for presuming a lack of mental capacity. The best course of action if to respect her decision but arrange follow-up after she has had time to think.

As mentioned previously an illogical decision is not grounds for presumption of mental incapacity. A psychiatric review is therefore inappropriate and is likely to alienate the patient.

Calling her daughter breaks confidentiality and is the worst option.

options: Watch a YouTube video of an endoscopy and then consent the patient
Read up on the procedure from a textbook and then consent the patient
Ask a senior colleague to explain the risks of the procedure to you and then consent the patient

Ask a senior colleague to consent the patient for you
questions:
You are a junior doctor and have just commenced a job in gastroenterology. Your consultant has asked you to consent a patient for an emergency endoscopy for upper GI bleeding. You have never done this procedure yourself but saw it performed during medical school. You do not feel confident in your knowledge of the procedure and its risks.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
If you are the doctor undertaking an investigation or providing treatment, it is your responsibility to discuss it with the patient. If this is not practical, you can delegate the responsibility to someone else, provided you make sure that the person delegate to:
  • Is suitably trained and qualified
  • Has sufficient knowledge of the proposed investigation or treatment, and understands the risks involved

From the scenario, you are not confident in your knowledge of the procedure and the risks, and therefore for you to consent the patient for this procedure would be wrong - the patient is unlikely to fully understand what they are providing their consent for and you may miss something important. This could have legal implications for you if something went wrong. Your consultant should not be asking you to do something you are not adequately trained for, and you are allowed to say no. However, if you can find someone who is capable of doing this task, i.e. a senior colleague (E), that is better than simply refusing to do it. There is a patient who requires an emergency endoscopy at the end of this therefore if not you then someone needs to consent them. This 'senior colleague' may even end up being the consultant who has delegated the task to you. All the other responses apart from (D) refusing to consent them, involve you doing something you do not feel confident or competent to do, and so refusal is the next best response.

Following this, the next best would be to ask someone to explain the procedure and its risks to you (C), then to read a medical textbook (B), then to watch a YouTube video (A).

title: Consent
body:
There are 3 types of consent:

1. Informed
2. Expressed
3. Implied

Consent forms used in UK NHS
Consent Form 1For competent adults who are able to consent for themselves where consciousness may be impaired (e.g. GA)
Consent Form 2For an adult consenting on behalf of a child where consciousness is impaired
Consent Form 3For an adult or child where consciousness is not impaired
Consent Form 4For adults who lack capacity to provide informed consent

Capacity
Key points include:
1. Understand and retain information
2. Patient believes the information to be true
3. Patient is able to weigh the information to make a decision
All patients must be assumed to have capacity

Consent in minors
Young children and older children who are not Gillick competent cannot consent for themselves. In British law the patient's biological mother can always provide consent. The childs father can consent if the parents are married (and the father is the biological father), or if the father is named on the birth certificate (irrespective of marital status). If parents are not married and the father is not named on the birth certificate then the father cannot consent.

options: Talk to Dr Kim about your concerns
Talk to your educational supervisor to ask for advice on the situation
Talk to Dr Kim's clinical supervisor to inform them about the situation
Don't interfere, its down to your seniors to deal with the situation

questions:
You are an F2 on a busy medical ward. Dr Kim, your fellow F2 is also on your ward. Dr Kim has made several prescribing errors that have resulted in a few near misses, but luckily no patient has come to harm.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This problem has happened several times and represents a patient safety issue. It is, therefore, appropriate to act.

As a first step, it is important to raise your concerns with the person involved (A), as it is good practice to speak directly to a colleague rather than go through an intermediary. If you are not sure what to do then your educational supervisor (B) may be a good source of information.

(C) Talking to Dr Kim's clinical supervisor is a logical step but by not speaking to them first it may damage your ongoing working relationship with them.

(E) This option does not involve any direct steps to tackle the problem. Additionally adding this extra workload to yourself may lead to you making mistakes.

(D) Doing nothing in this potentially dangerous situation is totally inappropriate and therefore ranks last.

GMC guidance states:


'If you have concerns that a colleague may not be fit to practise and may be putting patients at risk, you must ask for advice from a colleague, your defence body or us. If you are still concerned you must report this, in line with our guidance and your workplace policy, and make a record of the steps you have taken'

A patient calls you over to his bed to ask why his medication has been increased. He points to two warfarin tablets on his table and tells you that he normally only takes one. On reviewing his kardex you note that he should have only received one tablet. What should you do?

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes: Patient safety is always the number one priority and therefore you should immediately remove one of the tablets and advise him to take the correct dose (B).  The patient is aware of the mistake and so you should apologise to him (G).  It would also be advisable to speak to the nurse who dispensed the medication to establish how the error occurred (E).

questions:
You are a F2 doctor in general medicine. A 62-year-old man with COPD is admitted following an infective exacerbation. Despite controlled oxygen therapy, nebulisers and aminophylline he has a severe respiratory acidosis and is drowsy. He is unable to understand or retain any of the information you give him. His daughter shows you a copy of an advance directive stating he does not want any form of invasive or non-invasive ventilation. This was witnessed and co-signed and dated by his GP and solicitor.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC give the following guidance:
'Any valid advance refusal of treatment - one made when the patient was competent and on the basis of adequate information about the implications of his/her choice - is legally binding and must be respected where it is clearly applicable to the patient's present circumstances and where there is no reason to believe that the patient had changed his/her mind.'

Any advance directive refusing life-saving or life-prolonging treatment must be written, signed and dated by the patient and witnessed and signed by a third party - these criteria are met in this case.

The advance directive should be respected as it clearly states he does not want NIV. Given that the patient is likely to die without treatment it is sensible to speak to your Medical Indemnity Provider to confirm your actions. The advance statement relates to ventilation and other medical treatment should be continued as before.

Whilst family views should always be sought the patient has, in this situation, made an advance choice about treatment and that cannot be overruled.
